subject: Clean RabbitMQ definitions file
commit_message:
Clean RabbitMQ definitions file

Added a script to clean up the rabbitmq definitions file which is
being generated during the post-deployment phase of a deployment.
Previosly the definitions file contained all RPC queues presented in
RabbitMQ after the successful deployment. These queues are one-off, and
their restoration via OCF-script leads to growth of unconsumed messages,
which, in turn, lead to RabbitMQ slowness and malfunctions.

This is a rework of the previously reverted change
Ie3f3194b3eaaa8dc28d1cd3442090b586e177306 which caused deployment
failures in some scenarios involving partial update. This happened
because the script was delivered in a separate package which has not
been updated during the partial update. Now the script is
delivered in the puppet's directory instead. Also introduced
additional regexp-matching logic to instantly remove all the RPC queues,
which were left in the previous version of the fix.

Change-Id: Ib2f8237692d7dab47b83ac886ff370686a5d22fe
Closes-Bug: #1497961

subject: WADL to RST migration (part 1)
commit_message:
WADL to RST migration (part 1)

This brings the Images API Reference to the glance tree as part of
the effort described here:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/Migrate#API_Reference_Plan

This patch introduces (a) the tox environment to generate the api-ref,
and (b) the content of the Images v1 API reference converted to RST.
The content has been corrected where I noticed divergences with reality.

Note to reviewers: The conversion project is ongoing, that is, the doc
team is continuing to develop tools (for example, to display the response
codes in a table) and converging on a style for these docs.  So this isn't
a final product, there will be more patches later.  While this patch is
not perfect, it is pareto-optimal with respect to content (it's at least
as good as the current guide, and better in at least one place).  Thus
my advice, should you choose to take it, is that we should merge this
patch to get these docs in-tree, and make improvements as additional
patches that can focus on particular API calls rather than try to get

subject: Remove Packaging-Deb project team
commit_message:
Remove Packaging-Deb project team

The Packaging-Deb team was added August 13, 2015. Since that date
we added a requirement for minimum activity (following the rejection
of the Kosmos team), so it seems fair (after a decent grace period)
to revisit previously-approved official project teams based on that
new requirement.

The Packaging-Deb team specifies 25 repositories, of which only
one was created. That repository has two boilerplate commits[1].
Progress is not being discussed on the ML or in regular IRC
meetings. As far as OpenStack is concerned, this team basically
hasn't started yet.

When the issue was raised at the last PTL elections, Thomas Goirand
(the original team creator and main contributor) justified the
team existence in a ML thread[2]. In particular, the team is
actually active, but on alioth.debian.org git repositories.

While the team may be active, it is not an OpenStack project team,
it is a Debian project team, and all the visible work currently
happens there (on Debian git repositories and IRC channels). So I
don't think that should count toward "activity" for the OpenStack
official project team we are considering.

Thomas also said that progress is being stalled on getting a Debian
image supported in OpenStack Infrastructure, an objective that has
been lacking the necessary manpower or priority to be completed
until now. Being punted back to unofficial status would undo the
last 10 months efforts.

While this might have been true one year ago, we now no longer
undo anything when a project team is made unofficial, the git
repositories can stay up under the same name, and infrastructure
bits can be configured the same. So making the unborn project
"unofficial" does not undo any work that's been done, it only
reflects the actual status of the project team.

When the team starts working on the OpenStack side and the
repositories see some activity, I'll be more than happy to
reconsider adding this team. But for the time being we need
to remove it, if only to be fair with other nascent new teams
that we reject based on lack of past activity.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/deb-openstack-pkg-tools/log/
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-March/089369.html

subject: Add KMIP Experiment Check to Barbican
commit_message:
Add KMIP Experiment Check to Barbican

Barbican currently supports a plugin architecture for secret stores.
One such secret store implementation is the KMIP secret store. There
are no checks in place at the moment to test the functionality of
Barbican with this plugin.

This patch creates a new Jenkins job to test Barbican with the KMIP
secret store plugin. The end effect will be running all of Barbican's
functional tests using a KMIP secret store plugin. This change enables
the PyKMIP server to run as part of the devstack setup.

The tests can only be run on the latest code. The older stable
branches for kilo, liberty, and mitaka are not supported because the
necessary devstack plugin code is not backported to those branches.
The KMIP secret store job is experimental for now until tests verify
the correct operation.

commit_message:

Using the standard case of count(log_message) > 1, getting no
log_message measurements should be treated as OK. However, the old code
uses the emptyWindowObservationThreshold for both deterministic and
non-deterministic alarms which means that there must be 3 empty windows
before the deterministic alarm transitions to OK.

This change cause the evaluation of the Alarm to treat an empty window
as OK for deterministic alarms. So, count(log_message) > 1, getting no
measurements in a window will transition the alarm back to OK

subject: provide a replacement for the deprecated isotime()
commit_message:
provide a replacement for the deprecated isotime()

This change proposes a new timeutils.isoformat() to replace the earlier
one which was deprecated.

Several issues with the old isotime() function became apparent in
reviewing the steps required to handle the deprecation of
isotime(). These are detailed in the bug 1592181.

I strongly urge all reviewers to read the bug (referenced) and the
comments as part of the review.

WARNING: This code as proposed could introduce inconsistencies in the
way in which the earlier isotime() returns results. Specifically,
these two situations are known.

1. If you provide a timestamp that includes timezone information, the
old isotime() would wilfully ignore it, the new isoformat() function
will produce offset information in the resulting string. If the
timezone is UTC, you will get the 'Z' suffix, if it is non-UTC, you
will get the full 6 character offset +/-hh:mm.

2. If you provided isotime() with the subsecond parameter it returned
the (im)PERFECT_TIMESTAMP_FORMAT which included subsecond information
but NO timezone information. The new isoformat() returns timezone
information. If the timezone is UTC, you will get the 'Z' suffix, if
it is non-UTC, you will get the full 6 character offset +/-hh:mm.

In addition, a behavior which makes this implementation of isoformat()
differ from the original is that if you provide isoformat() with a
timestamp that includes invalid timezone information (such as an
offset greater than one day) then isoformat() will throw a
ValueError. The old isotime() was wilfully unaware and you wouldn't
get such an exception.

Tests have been proposed which exercise the new isoformat() function.

The term "wilfully unaware" that I use in the description above is
non-standard. It is not the same as 'naive'. Rather, 'wilfully
unaware' indicates code that knowingly treats timestamps as naive
without checking or making any consideration for whether they are
aware or naive.

I believe that this code, warts and all is better than having multiple
buggy copies of isotime() in each project; each just slightly
different from the other to make your skin crawl. It is generally
advisable when you have bad apples, to put them all together and away
from the good ones. This change attempts to do that.

Change-Id: Ifb367a1f96a663a1d54b1770b9d20bbffdba491c
Related: Ic5abf6669edd4f1a9fd62e61f437565aa887aebe
Closes-Bug: #1592181

subject: Add 'level playing field' requirement
commit_message:
Add 'level playing field' requirement

From an upstream perspective, I see us as being in the business
of providing open collaboration playing fields in order to build
projects to reach the OpenStack Mission. We collectively provide
resources (infra, horizontal teams, events...) in order to enable
that open collaboration.

An important characteristic of these open collaboration grounds
is that they need to be a level playing field, where no specific
organization is being given an unfair advantage. I expect the teams
that we bless as "official" project teams to operate in that fair
manner. Otherwise we end up blessing what is essentially a trojan
horse for a given organization, open-washing their project in the
process. Such a project can totally exist as an unofficial project
(and even be developed on OpenStack infrastructure) but I don't
think it should be given free space in our Design Summits or
benefit from "OpenStack community" branding.

So if, in a given project team, developers from one specific
organization benefit from access to specific knowledge or hardware
(think exclusive access to proprietary hardware or software that
the open source code primarily interfaces with), then this project
team should be rejected under the "open community" rule.

This requirement (like all requirements in this document) is meant
to be interpreted by humans on a case-by-case basis. In particular,
there is a grey area around drivers for proprietary solutions that
requires human judgment here. As a rule of thumb, if the open
implementation was unusable open core bait to lure people into
using the one and only proprietary driver, it would be a problem.
If the open implementation was fully functional and nothing
prevented adding additional proprietary drivers to the code base,
there would be no problem.

Change-Id: I0cd689afb8ddb7a269b9ce378e4c6647652f6977

subject: [WIP] OVS trunk bridge plugging for vlan-aware VMs
commit_message:
[WIP] OVS trunk bridge plugging for vlan-aware VMs

In order to provide vlan-aware VM functionality within the Neutron OVS
agent (in a way that would also be compatible with OVS-DPDK), an
instance's tap device needs to be attached to an OVS "trunk" bridge that
is then connected into the OVS integration bridge using a patch port
pair.

This is very similar to the current way that ovs_hybrid plugging works
today, except:
1) Nova creates an OVS bridge instead of a linux bridge (i.e. qbr) to
   attach the tap interface to.
2) Nova connects that bridge to the OVS integration bridge using a patch
   port pair instead of a veth pair.

By using an OVS bridge instead of a linux bridge as the tap interface
attach point, Neutron will be able to create additional patch port pairs
between the trunk bridge and the integration bridge with specific vlan
tags used to mux/demux vlan-tagged traffic to/from the VM and thereby
implement vlan-aware VMs functionality.

The responsibility of creating the OVS "trunk" bridge and connecting it
to the integration bridge via patch ports is left to Nova rather than
Neutron because it simplifies the overall work flow between
Nova/Neutron, similar to the reason why Nova is responsible for creating
the Linux bridge and veth pair in the ovs_hybrid strategy.

NOTE: as Nova is currently working towards integration with the os-vif
library (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/269672/), this patch (and
follow-ups) will most likely be merged to os-vif rather than Nova,
but feel free to add feedback to this patch (and follow-ups) until it's
ported to os-vif.

This patch only provides the initial plugging-related methods for VIFs
of the type ovs_trunk. Further dependent patches will drive the logic of
how these methods are actually called, based upon details in the VIF
object.

Change-Id: Ic43e5b539afb14b6682103a37ec58a5745d2ab01
Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms

subject: ICMP type & code validation while adding Security Group rules
commit_message:
ICMP type & code validation while adding Security Group rules

While adding new 'Security Group Rule' viz. 'Custom ICMP rule' when
wrong ICMP 'type' or 'code' was given the errors it would show were
'Not a valid port number'; which is misleading. The errors should
rather be 'Not a valid ICMP type' or 'Not a valid ICMP code'.

Also for validating ICMP 'type' and 'code' there wasn't any dedicated
functionality in 'oslo.utils/netutils' so the code for validating 'TCP
ports' was used. TCP ports are in range 0 to 65535 while ICMP 'type'
and 'code' are in range 0 to 255, so using 'TCP port validation' code
is incorrect.

When -1 is used in 'ICMP code' or 'ICMP type' that means any number
0 to 255 is valid.

Here newer dedicated functionality of 'oslo.utils/netutils' is used
for validating ICMP 'type' and ICMP 'code'.

subject: Adapt error response body in nova and cinder api
commit_message:
Adapt error response body in nova and cinder api

1. What is the problem
In the current controller implementation in nova_apigw and
cinder_apigw, pecan.abort is used to raise an exception when
error occurs. The problem of using pecan.abort is that the
response body doesn't have the same format with the error
response body in nova api and cinder api. Thus python client
may not correctly extract the error message, also, tempest
test may fail.

2. What is the solution to the problem
Replace pecan.abort with correct response body.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
   to realize the solution
In this patch, we remove pecan.abort calls in controllers
of nova and cinder resources and directly return the error
response body with correct format. Controllers for the Tricircle
api still keep pecan.abort calls since we don't have special
requirement on the format of error response body.

Change-Id: I0e6fe9ddfce3f001fee0be2160d24c9c628d0a88

subject: Add network type support to the Tricircle plugin
commit_message:
Add network type support to the Tricircle plugin

1. What is the problem
In the current implementation of the Tricircle plugin for neutron,
network type is not supported so users cannot create networks
with network type specified. In the specification of cross-pod
l2 networking feature[1], we decide to support several network
types like local, shared VLAN, shared VxLAN, etc, the first step
is to make the Tricircle plugin be aware of network type.

2. What is the solution to the problem
Handle network type in the Tricircle plugin for neutron.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
   to realize the solution
In this patch, we add a framework to load type driver which
processes different network type. The framework is based on
neutron ML2 implemenation, we inherit the ML2 type manager and
create a new Tricircle type manager. Also the Tricircle plugin
is modified to extract network type parameter from request and
insert network type information to response.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tricircle/blob/master/specs/cross-pod-l2-networking.rst

Change-Id: Ida9b88df6113db46e637a7841ce5c1adaf651eba
